    Team News

    Liverpool
    • Naby Keita is out for the remainder of the season with a groin injury sustained in the first leg, which should lead to a midfield three of Georgino Wijnaldum, Fabinho and Jordan Henderson.
    • Mohamed Salah was forced off in the second half of Liverpool's 3-2 win at Newcastle after a nasty collision with Martin Dubravka, but watched the remainder of the game in the dressing room and showed no ill-effects.
    • However Jurgen Klopp has announced that Salah has unavailable, which is a blow as the Reds boss has confirmed that Roberto Firmino is ruled out, while Adam Lallana is a doubt.
    Barcelona
    • Ousmane Dembele sustained a hamstring injury at Celta Vigo and misses out for Barcelona.
    • Rafinha is the only other injury concern for the La Liga side.
    • Ernesto Valverde may name the same XI that started the 3-0 first leg win at Camp Nou.

    Prediction

    • Liverpool have it all to do in the second leg at Anfield, but with the fans in full voice, they'll be confident of making things difficult for Barcelona. If they can nick an early goal, they'll have the wind in their sails as they look to pull off a huge result to secure a Champions League final spot.
    • However, opponents Barcelona have already wrapped up the title and it saw Ernesto Valverde rest a number of first team regulars for the weekend loss at Celta Vigo. Prior to that loss, the Blaugrana were unbeaten in 11 away from home as they gun for European glory.
    • There promises to be an electric atmosphere at Anfield on Tuesday night, but if Lionel Messi shines once again, then it's Barcelona who should secure their place in the Champions League final, particularly with Mohamed Salah and Roberto Firmino ruled out.
    Prediction:
    Liverpool
    1
    2
    Barcelona

    • [ - ] blackbird - member since 18-Aug-18

      @k.1 ...Nobody thinks Liverpool plays the same as Barcelona. And yeah, Barcelona do need fast-paced wingers, but Dembele was injured, and only Valverde knows why he decided against playing Malcolm. He probably thought Jordi Alba was enough. However, fast-paced wingers and players with technical ability are not mutually exclusive. Guardiola's Barcelona had both. Another issue is that there is actually a decrease in the amount of highly technical, intelligent players on the current Barcelona team compared with before. It's not that Barcelona need to "evolve" (suggesting that they are outdated), it's that they've "devolved" and are stuck in some weird middle place where they can't dominate possession as much (not enough intelligent technical players) and they can't play counter-attack effectively (not enough fast forwards). Also, people's problem w/ Semedo is not that he can't make short passes, it's that when he gets the ball he doesn't know what to do, so he's often a useless option.
